{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Youssef Seddik | honorific_suffix = | native_name = يوسف الصديق | native_name_lang = Tunisian Arabic | image = Youssef Seddik (cropped).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1943 | birth_place = [[Tozeur]], [[French Tunisia]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | monuments = | residence = | nationality = [[Tunisia]]n | other_names = | ethnicity = <!-- Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Philosopher]] and [[anthropologist]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | denomination = <!-- Denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | spouse = | partner = <!-- unmarried life partner; use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Youssef Seddik''' ({{lang-aeb|يوسف الصديق}}) (born in 1943 in [[Tozeur]]) is a noted [[Tunisia]]n [[philosopher]] and [[anthropologist]] specializing in [[Ancient Greece]] and the anthropology of the [[Qur'an]].
==Biography==
In 1966, he obtained a master's degree in philosophy and a degree in French literature and civilization. During the next four years, he taught at the French school in [[Compiègne]] in 1967 and obtained a DES (''{{Interlanguage link multi|diplôme d'études supérieures|fr}}'', roughly equivalent to an [[Master of Arts|MA]]) in Philosophy and a degree in Ancient Greece.<ref name="arte">{{fr icon}} [http://www.arte.tv/fr/permis-de-penser/Ce-mois-ci/834976.html Portrait of Youssef Seddik] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821165909/http://www.arte.tv/fr/permis-de-penser/Ce-mois-ci/834976.html |date=August 21, 2009 }}</ref>
From 1971 to 1977 he taught philosophy in secondary schools in Tunisia and at the [[University of Paris III: Sorbonne Nouvelle]], before becoming director of a publishing company specializing in books for young people between 1984 and 1987. He was also a reporter of the journal ''[[La Presse de Tunisie]]'' between 1975 and 1983.<ref name="RF">{{cite web|url=http://sites.radiofrance.fr/chaines/france-culture2/emissions/camedit/fiche.php?diffusion_id=57308 |title=Youssef Seddik |publisher=[[Radio France]] |accessdate=August 22, 2009 |language=fr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901003134/http://sites.radiofrance.fr/chaines/france-culture2/emissions/camedit/fiche.php?diffusion_id=57308 |archivedate=September 1, 2009 }}</ref>
Based in [[Paris]] in 1988, he obtained a DEA in the Greek language and civilization from the University of Paris III: Sorbonne Nouvelle (1988) and a doctorate at the [[École des hautes études en sciences sociales]] (1995).<ref name="arte"/> He lectured there and also in modern Islamic philosophy at the Sorbonne from 1995 to 1996.
Seddik has published many books and translations based on Ancient Greece and Islamic heritage, including works related to the Prophet [[Muhammad]], [[Imam Ali]], and the [[Qur'an]]. He also attempted to publish a Qur'an in the form of seven volumes of comics, but was halted after objections from the Tunisian religious authorities in 1992.<ref name="RF"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iesr.ephe.sorbonne.fr/index3689.html|title=Seddik, Youssef|publisher=European Institute of Sciences and Religions|accessdate=August 22, 2009|language=fr}}</ref>
In 1999 he published a book entitled ''Brins de chicane. La vie quotidienne à Bagdad au Xe siècle'' about daily life in [[Baghdad]] in the tenth century.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ellipse.ch/Produit.aspx?Produit=899938 |title=Brins de chicane. La vie quotidienne à Bagdad au Xe siècle |publisher=Ellipse Librairie |accessdate=August 22, 2009 |language=fr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706231536/http://www.ellipse.ch/Produit.aspx?Produit=899938 |archivedate=July 6, 2011 }}</ref> His book, ''Nous n'avons jamais lu le Coran'', released in September 2004 explores the language and symbols that are present in the Koran. In the book the author begins with the questioning of the politics of Islam and the role of God.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://livre.fnac.com/a1553849/Youssef-Seddik-Nous-n-avons-jamais-lu-le-Coran?PID=1|title=Nous n'avons jamais lu le Coran |publisher=livre.fnac.com|accessdate=August 22, 2009|language=fr}}</ref>
He also directed documentaries including a series of five episodes on Muhammad.<ref name="arte"/>

Première somme de la jurisprudence islamique'' (editing and translation of the book of Mâlik ibn Anas), ed. Des révolutions arabes aux indignés'' (Interview with Gilles Vanderpooten), ed. L'Aube, La Tour d'Aigues, 2011 * ''Tunisie, la Révolution inachevée'' (Interview with Gilles Vanderpooten), ed. L'Aube, La Tour d'Aigues, 2014 ({{ISBN|281591008X}}) * ''Ce que le Coran doit à la Bible : un dialogue contemporain sur l'islam et le judaïsme'' (With Isy Morgensztern), Paris, La Découverte, 2018
